Teaching & Outreach

I enjoy being able to talk about all things astrophysics, whether that is in the context of teaching in lectures, mentoring students or participating in outreach events. I have been a speaker at a few events, e.g. at the Big Bang Bash of the Edinburgh International Science Festival in 2016, or for the Mimikry: Exomoon immersive play at the Theater am Neumarkt in Zurich in 2023. Additionally, I have been an interviewee for school students working on galaxy-related projects in the canton of Zurich.

One aspect I particularly enjoy about outreach is coming up with memorable and engaging ways to convey the material in accessible ways. As such I have written a couple of dances and poems about star formation, astrochemistry, galaxy formation and evolution. Please get in touch if you are interested in me giving a talk/writing a dance/poem for your event.

Teaching & Mentoring

  • prepared and taught the lectures on galaxy formation and evolution for AST 202 The Universe: Contents, Origin, Evolution and Future (University of Zurich; summer semester 2023)
  • tutored Introduction to Astronomy and Astrophysics (Heidelberg University; winter semester 2018/2019, 2019/2020)
  • tutored Experimental Physics I (Heidelberg University; Oct-Dec 2018)
  • co-supervisor of University of Zurich PhD student Elia Cenci (2021-)
  • academic mentor of University of Zurich PhD student Mauro Bernardini (2021-2023)
  • academic mentor of Heidelberg University BSc/MSc student Luise Kluge (2020-2022)
  • main supervisor of summer internship and Bachelor thesis for Heidelberg University student Leon Fordinal (It’s cloudy out there: The effect of galactic potentials on cloud properties; 2020 - 2021)

Dances

Many complex astrophysical processes can be broken down into a combination geometrical patterns and simple movements, aka dances.

I have collaborated with Science Ceilidh, who do a fantastic job of writing Ceilidh dances about all sorts of STEM subjects, to write Stardust, a Ceilidh dance about the lifecycle of stars.

I also wrote Dustborne, a rather complicated Scottish country dance medley, about star formation and primordial astrochemistry and am working on a Highland dance about radiative transfer processes in the interstellar medium.

Poems

I have written Song of the Galaxies as a short summary of the contents of my galaxy formation and evolution lectures. It is a rewrite of Shakespeare’s famous Song of the Witches from Macbeth, with the analogy of galaxies as cosmic cauldrons.

We’re all made of stardust was written in the context of the lecture performance for Mimikry: Exomoon, with the aim to both convey information about the lifecyle of interstellar gas and nucleosynthesis, in addition to inviting reflection about the question at the core of the play: who will we become if given the chance to start a new life on a space settlement far, far away from Earth?
